text: I don’t rush forward.
The blizzard is too fierce. The shield wall too tight. The Demon King too close. Every reason presses against my chest like a stone, forcing that step back down my throat.
I tell myself: she said ‘don’t move.’ She said ‘hold your ground.’ If I don’t get in the way, that’s already helping.
But I know the truth—that’s just fear dressed up as obedience.
The necklace burns in Alicia’s hand, glowing red in the black light like heated iron.
The Demon King senses termination. The mist surges violently, crashing toward her wrist.
Her fingers tremble—not from fear, but from exhaustion crashing down.
That instant. That single instant. And I do nothing.
The Demon King’s voice layers over itself in countless whispers: “Re—turn—”
The sound grinds along bone. The mist tightens as if obeying command, coiling around her wrists, ankles, throat.
Alicia’s breathing grows shallow. She doesn’t look back at me. She only steadies her blade toward the core.
She tries to force the necklace into place—but the mist clamps onto it like a living jaw.
She strains. Her knuckles whiten. Veins rise along her hand. The pendant advances half an inch—then is dragged back.
The Demon King’s claw descends. Not a strike—correction. Pressing her back toward the rift. Back into the loop. Back into fate’s old alignment.
She raises her arm to block. Her knee slams into the snow, carving a crater. Her shoulder armor bursts. Blood seeps down her gauntlet, black against the white.
She still steps forward—closing distance the only way she ever does: trading her life for an opening.
But this time, no one steals that half-second for her.
The mist recoils and lashes back, freezing into chains around her throat and limbs. Her body is yanked upward, suspended before the core.
Her sword falls into the snow with a dull, final sound.
That sound makes me understand: I am still standing—and she is losing everything.
Her lips move. Maybe a command to retreat. Maybe—at last—a goodbye.
The mist crushes the words before they form. Her eyes remain bright—then slowly lose focus.
The Demon King presses her toward the rift. Not tearing—erasing. Like wiping a name from the world.
In the next heartbeat, Alicia is swallowed by black light—necklace and all—gone without trace.
The wind pauses. Not because it stops—because my world does.
I try to run forward—but my legs are lead. My throat locks, releasing only broken gasps.
Someone shouts behind the shield wall, someone tries to pull me back—but I can’t hear them.
The barrier’s blue light fractures, shards falling like glass. The soldiers’ breathing turns to panic.
The core in the Demon King’s chest brightens again—terribly stable. The loop continues.
Black mist floods outward in a tidal wave, rolling over snow and shields alike. The city walls groan as if splitting apart.
Cold pierces my chest—as if the world has passed sentence. As darkness swallows my sight, one thought remains: I didn’t save her. I didn’t even try.

event.message:
You stood still.

She stepped forward.

And then she was gone.

The loop continues.

This time,
you did nothing.

—— Standing Aside · BAD END ——
